description.text: IOA YANG module describing the Security model.
YANG Models for Infinera Open API (IOA) for release R6.1
YANG Models for Infinera Open API (IOA) for release R6.0
YANG Models for Infinera Open API (IOA) for release R5.2
YANG Models for Infinera Open API (IOA) for release R5.1
YANG Models for Infinera Open API (IOA) for release R5.0
YANG Models for Infinera Open API (IOA) for release R4.1
RSA key algorithm using SHA-1 hash.
RSA key algorithm using SHA-256 hash.
RSA key algorithm using SHA-512 hash.
ECDSA key algorithm on the nistp256 curve using SHA-256 hash.
ECDSA key algorithm on the nistp384 curve using SHA-384 hash.
ECDSA key algorithm on the nistp521 curve using SHA-512 hash.
Key algorithms (and signatures) supported for SSH host keys and public keys.
Top level security container.
Container with several flags that represent security policies of the system.

If enabled, non-secure protocols are not supported.
If disabled, non-secure protocols can be used, including:
- HTTP protocol for file transfer, REST API, or any other HTTP based application
- FTP protocol for file transfer
- SNMPv2c or SNMPv3 without encryption

Enabling secure-mode will be rejected if any non-secure protocol is in use.

If enabled, ensures the strict password complexity rules. Including:
- minimum length of 8 characters
- at least one lower case letter (a-z)
- at least one upper case letter (A-Z)
- at least one number (0-9)
- at least one symbol ()
- user name cannot be part of the password
If disabled, all these rules are not enforced, except:
- minimum length is 1 character
Once enabled, this policy only has impact on newly defined passwords.
Use password-based authentication for SSH access.
Use public key authentication for SSH access.

The method used to authenticate user for SSH access.
Note: For two-factor authentication, use public-key method and employ PIN/password-protected hardware device (e.g.: smart card or USB token.)

If enabled, ensures that a new password being set cannot match any of the previous 5 password
for the user.
If disabled, password repetition is allowed.
Once enabled, this policy only has impact on newly defined passwords.
Authentication locally only
Authentication locally first, if not pass, then use remote AAA server
Authentication use remote AAA server first, if remote authentication failed or all servers could not be contacted, then authenticate locally
Authentication use remote AAA server first, if all servers could not be contacted, then authenticate locally
Specify authentication method for the user login to the NE.
Authorization locally only.
Local users should follow local permissions and remote users should follow the remote ones.
All users (local or remote) should follow remote permissions. If the permissions return unavailable, then use local ones.
Specify authorization policy for the logged user. If the user changes this parameter, it should logout and login again to apply the rules.
Only allow connection to a remote ssh/sftp/scp host if identity provided by remote host is known
Allow connection to a remote ssh/sftp/scp host, regardless if identity provided by remote host is known
Specify the strictness of remote ssh/sftp/scp host identity checking.
The password of the root user.
The password of the console-user.

A switch to enable/disable console-user.
The console-user account is an emergency account that is only usable through the serial console.
Disabling this account may put the device in a position where recovery is not possible,
so it is recommended to keep this account enabled.
Critical Security Parameters symmetrical key.

The maximum number of management sessions that the system supports.
Note: session via serial console does not count against this maximum.
The maximum number of local users that can be configured in the system.

This policy allows to enable/disable user lockout when multiple invalid logins are detected.
The number of invalid logins that trigger the lockout is configurable at the individual user level with the max-invalid-logins parameter.
The time the user is locked-out is also configurable at user level with the suspension-time parameter.
Use TLS version 1.2 only.
Use TLS version 1.3 only.
Try to use TLS version 1.3 but if it fails use version 1.2.
Transport Layer Security (TLS) supported version(s). Changing this attribute will not affect existing connections.
This policy allows to enable/disable CRL-based certificate revocation.

Specifies the maximum time to wait (in seconds) for automatic CRL downloads.
Note: This timeout does not apply to manual CRL downloads.
This policy defines whether OCSP responders can be consulted for certificate revocation checking.
Default roles for users access.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Counter mode.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 192-bit key in Counter mode.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Counter mode.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Galois/Counter mode.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Galois/Counter mode.
ChaCha20 stream cipher and Poly1305 MAC.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode.
Allowed symmetric ciphers for SSH.
256-bit hash-based MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-2.
512-bit hash-based MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-2.
256-bit Encrypt-then-MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-2.
512-bit Encrypt-then-MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-2.
160-bit hash-based MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-1.
Truncated 160-bit hash-based MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-1.
160-bit Encrypt-then-MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-1.
Truncated 160-bit Encrypt-then-MAC using Secure Hash Algorithm-1.
Allowed message authentication code algorithms for SSH.
Diffie-Hellman group exchange algorithm using Secure Hash Algorithm-2.

ECDH key exchange algorithm with ephemeral keys generated on the nistp256 curve using
Secure Hash Algorithm-2.

ECDH key exchange algorithm with ephemeral keys generated on the nistp384 curve using
Secure Hash Algorithm-2.

ECDH key exchange algorithm with ephemeral keys generated on the nistp521 curve using
Secure Hash Algorithm-2.
Diffie-Hellman group 14 key exchange algorithm using Secure Hash Algorithm-1.
Diffie-Hellman group exchange algorithm using Secure Hash Algorithm-1.
Allowed key exchange algorithms for SSH.
Allowed host key algorithms for SSH.
Allowed public key algorithms for SSH.

Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral,
Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral,
Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 384.

Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 384.

Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 384.

Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral,
Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral,
Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 384.

Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral,
Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 384.

Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Cipher Block Chaining mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 256.

Rivest Shamir Adleman algorithm,
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Galois/Counter mode,
Secure Hash Algorithm 384.
Supported TLS 1.2 cipher suites. Changing this attribute will not affect existing connections.
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Galois/Counter mode (Secure Hash Algorithm 256).
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key in Galois/Counter mode (Secure Hash Algorithm 384).
ChaCha stream cipher and Poly1305 authenticator (Secure Hash Algorithm 256).
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Counter with CBC-MAC mode (Secure Hash Algorithm 256).
Advanced Encryption Standard with 128-bit key in Counter with CBC-MAC mode with 8-Octet ICV (Secure Hash Algorithm 256).

Supported TLS 1.3 cipher suites. Changing this attribute will not affect existing connections.
TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 note:
If present and requested by the client, it will be prioritized regardless of cipher-suite order.
256-bit Elliptic-curve Diffie-Hellman using curve SECP256r1.
384-bit Elliptic-curve Diffie-Hellman using curve SECP384r1.
521-bit Elliptic-curve Diffie-Hellman using curve SECP521r1.
256-bit Elliptic-curve Diffie-Hellman using curve 25519.
448-bit Elliptic-curve Diffie-Hellman using curve 448.

Supported elliptic curve algorithms.
The tls-curve algorithm affects both key-exchange and authentication stages of TLS handshake.
Changing this attribute will not affect existing connections.
Applies to both TLS 1.2 and 1.3.
NOTE: Restricting curves can cause interoperability issues.
TLS 1.2 remark: if the configured curve is not sent by the client, handshake may fail.
TLS 1.3 remark: for the Authentication stage, it is possible that the server
selects another curve different from the certificate signing algorithm.
User details. Can represent both locally configured users, as well as temporary remote users.
The name of the user.
The password of the user.

Hashed password of the user. It is made of three mandatory fields,
where the dollar sign is the field separator. The structure is: $id$salt$encrypted
Only id 6 (SHA512) is supported. Salt minimum size is 2.
reference: https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/crypt.3.html
The display name for this user.

This attribute is the maximum number of consecutive and invalid login attempts
before an account is suspended (lockedout). Zero disables escalation on login failure.

This attribute is the duration of UID suspension following consecutive invalid login attempts.
Setting the value to 0 disables this behavior.

This attribute is the Session Time Out Interval. If there are no messages between the user
and the NE over the Time Out interval, the session is logged off. Setting the value to 0 disables
this attribute (meaning the session will not time out).
This attribute is the Password Aging Interval. Setting the value to 0 disables password aging.
This attribute shows the password expiration date.
Enable switch for the user, allows admins to explicitly disable users.

This attribute shows the user status.
User with status 'enabled' will have access to the system.
User with status 'disabled' not have access to the system.
User with status 'password-aged' will have access to the system but will be forced to change his password on first-time login.
User with status 'lockout' means the account is locked out due to unsuccessful login attempts.
Allows administrator to force user to change password on next login.
This attribute specifies the maximum number of sessions allowed for this user.
The last login date/time of the user.
Number of previous failed logins. Resets to zero upon a successful login.
User is authenticated locally.
User is authenticated through remote AAA server.
Indicates the authentication method of the user.
Associated user groups for this user.

List of user groups, each one with its own access permissions.
Each user will be associated with a list of groups, and will derive its permissions from them.
Name of the group.
Long description of the user group.
List of currently established management layer sessions.

Specifies a unique identifier of the current session. It indicates the
IP address and transport layer port number associated with this session.
If the session is initiated from the serial port, the value is 'NA'.
User name associated with this session.
Session type.
Indicates which protocol has been used to establish the session.
The timestamp the user has created this session.
Local ip address of the session
Name of the dial-out-server associated with this session.
Configuration of AAA servers - RADIUS or TACACS+.
specify the name of aaa server.
This is used to sort the servers in the order of precedence.
specify the protocol used for AAA.
The IP address of AAA server.
AAA server port number.
AAA server authentication port number.
AAA server accounting port number.
The shared secret of the aaa server. The shared secret will be displayed as *.
The configured roles for the AAA server.
Enable switch for this aaa-server.
Specifies the response timeout of Access-Request messages sent to a AAA server in seconds.
Specifies the number of attempted Access-Request messages to a single AAA server before failing authentication.
Source IP address used for RADIUS communications.

Password used for RADIUS authorization after SSH public key authentication.
If blank, username is reused as password for RADIUS authorization.
